body:
### Chaining Operators
chaining operators together allows a lot of saved keystrokes in coffee. 

in coffee:
```coffee
mynumber=34

if 25 <= mynumber <= 50
	console.log "its between 24 and 50"
else
	console.log "its greater than 50 or less than 24"
```

The same operators in JS would look like this:
```javascript
if ((24 <= mynumber && mynumber <= 50)){
...
}
```

***

### No commas! (if you want)
Objects + arrays are really straight forward and awesome in coffee-script. But the best part there is no need for all those silly commas in array declarations (if you put each item on its own line).


for example:
```coffee
user =
	name: "Ryan Whalen"
	username: "RyWhal"
	age: 26

    #No Commas in the array declaration 
	Aliases: [
		'RyWhal'
		'RJPW'
	]
	websites: [
		'ryanwhalen.me'
		'slur.pe'
		'blackholeoftheinternet.com'
		'rywhal.github.io'
	]
        
    #or you can use commas
	emails: ['ryan@ryan.com','whalen@whalen.com']
console.log user
```


output of the printed object:
```
{ name: 'Ryan Whalen',
  username: 'RyWhal',
  age: 26,
  Aliases: [ 'RyWhal', 'RJPW' ],
  websites:
   [ 'ryanwhalen.me',
     'slur.pe',
     'blackholeoftheinternet.com',
     'rywhal.github.io' ],
  emails: [ 'ryan@ryan.com', 'whalen@whalen.com' ] }
```

### I needed some encouragement
An array of encouragements and some math for a random entry will do nicely

uncompiled encourage.coffee
```coffee
encouragements = [
	"You're doing great!",
	"You are the best I've ever seen!",
	"You are the wind beneath my wings",
	"You have no equal",
	"Woooooo!",
	"Keep going!..",
	"You can do it.",
]

length = encouragements.length

console.log encouragements[Math.floor Math.random() * length]
```

output:
```sh
~/Projects/coffee ⌚ 23:57:58
$ node encourage.js
Keep going!..

~/Projects/coffee ⌚ 23:58:01
$ node encourage.js
You have no equal

~/Projects/coffee ⌚ 23:58:02
$ node encourage.js
You can do it.
```

### Making Classes and Functions 
So everything is pretty plain language created in coffee-script. Creating a class is as easy as "class ClasName" and giving it a constructor with some attributes. 

A function is easily created with a statement like "function_name: ->". The preceding indented lines are part of that function. Functions have implicit returns, too!

uncompiled info_print.coffee
```coffee
class Info

	constructor: (@attributes)->

	printInfo: ->
		console.log "Name: #{@attributes.name}"
		console.log "Title: #{@attributes.title}"
		console.log "DOB: #{@attributes.dob}"
		if @attributes.salary
			console.log "Salary: #{@attributes.salary}"
		else
			console.log "Salary: Unknown"

ryan = new Info
	name: "Ryan"
	title: "Tech"
	dob: new Date(1988, 2, 2)
	salary: "$1,000,000"

ross = new Info
	name: "Ross S."
	title: "VP"
	dob: new Date(1985, 7, 15)

ryan.printInfo()
console.log " "
ross.printInfo()
```

after its compiled and run:
```
$ node info_print.js
Name: Ryan
Title: Tech
DOB: Wed Mar 02 1988 00:00:00 GMT+0000 (UTC)
Salary: $1,000,000

Name: Ross S.
Title: VP
DOB: Thu Aug 15 1985 00:00:00 GMT+0000 (UTC)
Salary: Unknown
```

### Hello World
Turns out a hello world script is pretty easy in coffee script. It's easy to see how coffee script can save you time when you compare the .coffee and .js files.


uncompiled hello.coffee:
```coffee
hello = "Hello, World"
console.log hello
```


compiled into js:
```javascript
(function() {
  var hello;

  hello = "Hello, World";

  console.log(hello);

}).call(this);
```
